greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The number of divisors d of n of the form d == 1 (mod 8).
comment: a(n) >= 1 as the divisor d=1 is always counted.
The largest terms up to n = 10^6 are each equal to 24. Those 8 terms are for n = 675675, 765765, 799425, 855855, 863379, 883575, 945945, or 987525. - _Harvey P. Dale_, May 31 2017

a(n) can be computed from the prime factorization of n. Let v(n) = (n1, n3, n5, n7) where n_r  is the number of divisors of n in class r (mod 8) (we do not care about even remainders). Then if gcd(k, m) = 1 we have v(k) = (k1, k3, k5, k7) so a(k) = k1, v(m) = (m1, m3, m5, m7) so a(m) = k1.
We have a(k*m) = (km)_1 = k1*m1 + k2*m2 + k3*m3 + k4*m4. The other (km)_3..(km)_7 have a similar expression.
if p == 1 (mod 8) then a(p^e) = e + 1 otherwise floor(e/2) + 1. (End)
link: David A. Corneth, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: G.f.: Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(1 - x^(8*k)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Sep 11 2019
maple: sigmamr := proc(n,m,r) local a,d ; a := 0 ; for d in numtheory[divisors](n) do if modp(d,m) = r then a := a+1 ; end if; end do: a; end proc:
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(d = divisors(n)); #select(x -> x%8 == 1, d)} \\ _David A. Corneth_, Apr 06 2021
(PARI) See PARI link \\ _David A. Corneth_, Apr 06 2021
results.author: _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 23 2011
